skills.name: Basic Athletic Stance
skills.summary: The foundation of all skiing. A balanced, athletic stance allows you to move efficiently and respond to terrain changes.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Struggling to maintain balance on flat terrain
outcomeMilestones.developing: Can hold stance briefly but loses balance easily
outcomeMilestones.confident: Maintains athletic stance comfortably on gentle terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Stance is automatic and adaptable to changing terrain

tips.title: Athletic Ready Position
tips.content: Imagine you're about to catch a ball - that athletic ready position is your ski stance.

tips.title: Shin Pressure Check
tips.content: Your shins should gently press against the front of your boots. If you can wiggle your heels, you're in the right position.

tips.title: Hand Position
tips.content: Keep your hands where you can see them in your peripheral vision - about belly button height and slightly forward.

drills.title: Statue Check
drills.overview: Stop on flat terrain and check your body position from bottom to top.

steps.instruction: Come to a complete stop on gentle terrain
Without moving, scan your body from feet to head
Check: Are your ankles flexed? Knees bent? Hips hinged?
Adjust any areas that feel locked or rigid
Hold this position and memorize how it feels

items.text: Boots buckled snugly but not painfully tight
Joints flexed and ready to move

skills.name: Straight Run & Gliding
skills.summary: Learn to glide on flat terrain while maintaining your athletic stance.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot maintain balance while skis are moving
outcomeMilestones.developing: Can glide short distances with some wobbling
outcomeMilestones.confident: Glides smoothly on flat terrain with good balance
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Glides effortlessly and can adjust stance while moving

videos.title: First Day on Skis - Straight Run

tips.title: Look Ahead
tips.content: Look where you want to go, not at your ski tips. Your body follows your eyes.

tips.title: Quiet Upper Body
tips.content: Keep your upper body still and quiet. Let your legs do the work underneath you.

tips.title: Flat Skis Mental Cue
tips.content: Imagine your skis are floating on water - keep them flat and level as you glide.

tips.title: Arms for Balance
tips.content: Use your arms like a tightrope walker - they're your natural balance aids.

drills.title: Scooter Push Drill
drills.overview: Practice gliding by pushing with one ski like a scooter.

steps.instruction: Find a flat area with your skis on
Take off one ski and hold it or set it aside
Push yourself along using your boot foot like a scooter
Focus on balancing on the gliding ski as long as possible
Switch feet and repeat

skills.name: Wedge (Pizza) Position
skills.summary: The wedge or 'pizza' shape is your first tool for controlling speed.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot form a wedge shape with skis
outcomeMilestones.developing: Can form wedge but struggles to maintain it while moving
outcomeMilestones.confident: Holds a stable wedge position to control speed
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Can vary wedge size smoothly to adjust speed

tips.title: Toes Together, Heels Apart
tips.content: Imagine your skis are a slice of pizza - tips close together, tails spread apart.

tips.title: Inside Edges
tips.content: Gently roll your ankles inward to engage the inside edges of both skis.

tips.title: Push Out, Not Down
tips.content: Push your heels outward, not downward. The movement comes from your legs, not your weight.

tips.title: Knees Over Toes
tips.content: Keep your knees bent and tracking over your toes to maintain a strong, stable position.

tips.title: Size Controls Speed
tips.content: Bigger pizza = more braking. Smaller pizza = less braking. Adjust size to control speed.

drills.title: Wedge Width Control
drills.overview: Practice making your wedge bigger and smaller while standing still.

steps.instruction: Start in a gliding straight run on gentle terrain
Push your heels out to form a small wedge
Gradually make the wedge bigger - notice how you slow down
Bring skis back toward parallel
Repeat: small wedge, big wedge, release

skills.name: Wedge Turns
skills.summary: Your first turns! Use the wedge position to control direction.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot change direction in a wedge
outcomeMilestones.developing: Makes wide, hesitant turns with inconsistent shape
outcomeMilestones.confident: Links wedge turns smoothly with good speed control
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Makes confident, rounded turns in either direction

tips.title: Pressure the Outside Ski
tips.content: To turn left, put more weight on your right ski. To turn right, weight your left ski.

tips.title: Look Through the Turn
tips.content: Turn your head to look where you want to go - your body will follow.

tips.title: Heavy Foot Turns
tips.content: Think 'heavy foot' on the ski you want to turn away from. Heavy right foot = turn left.

tips.title: Patience in the Turn
tips.content: Let the turn happen. Don't rush - hold pressure on the outside ski and let your skis arc around.

tips.title: Hands Forward
tips.content: Keep your hands in front of you where you can see them. This keeps your weight forward and balanced.

drills.title: Falling Leaf Drill
drills.overview: Traverse across the slope, making gentle turns like a falling leaf.

steps.instruction: Start in a wedge, pointing across the slope
Glide across the slope in a slight downward traverse
Shift weight to your downhill ski to turn uphill and stop
Shift weight to uphill ski to turn back across the slope
Continue zig-zagging down like a falling leaf

skills.name: Wedge Stop
skills.summary: The essential skill of stopping safely and in control.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot stop reliably on gentle terrain
outcomeMilestones.developing: Stops eventually but takes too long or loses balance
outcomeMilestones.confident: Stops quickly and in control on green terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Stops precisely where intended with confidence

tips.title: Widen and Edge
tips.content: To stop, make a bigger wedge and press harder on the inside edges of both skis.

tips.title: Push Through Your Heels
tips.content: Drive your heels outward as if you're trying to spread the snow. Feel the resistance build.

tips.title: Stay Centered
tips.content: Keep your weight centered - don't lean back! Leaning back makes stopping harder.

tips.title: Plan Your Stop
tips.content: Pick a spot ahead where you want to stop. Start widening your wedge early - stopping takes distance.

drills.title: Target Stop Drill
drills.overview: Practice stopping at specific targets to improve precision.

steps.instruction: Find a gentle slope with a flat run-out
Place a glove or marker where you want to stop
Glide toward the marker in a small wedge
Begin widening your wedge well before the marker
Try to stop exactly at the marker
Adjust starting distance based on results

warnings.title: Always Know How to Stop
warnings.content: Never ski faster than you can safely stop. This is your most important safety skill.

skills.name: Wedge Christie
skills.summary: Transition from wedge turns to more efficient parallel skiing.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot bring skis parallel at any point in the turn
outcomeMilestones.developing: Occasionally matches skis at the end of turns
outcomeMilestones.confident: Consistently brings skis parallel in the second half of turns
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Smooth transition from wedge initiation to parallel finish

tips.title: Match at the End
tips.content: Start in a wedge, but as you complete the turn, slide your inside ski parallel to match the outside ski.

tips.title: Steering the Inside Ski
tips.content: Actively steer your inside (uphill) ski to match the outside ski. Don't just wait for it to happen.

tips.title: Two Phases Mental Model
tips.content: Think of the turn in two phases: Phase 1 - wedge to initiate. Phase 2 - match and glide parallel.

tips.title: Earlier Matching
tips.content: As you improve, try to match your skis earlier in the turn. Eventually you won't need the wedge at all.

tips.title: Commit to the Outside Ski
tips.content: Once you start the turn, commit your weight fully to the outside ski. This makes matching natural.

drills.title: Match and Glide Drill
drills.overview: Focus on the matching phase by holding it longer.

steps.instruction: Start a wedge turn as normal
As you come across the fall line, match your skis
Hold the parallel position and glide for 3 seconds
Begin the next turn with a small wedge
Repeat, gradually reducing the wedge phase

skills.name: Traverse & Sideslip
skills.summary: Control your path across the slope and slip sideways when needed.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot maintain a traverse line without sliding downhill
outcomeMilestones.developing: Traverses but with inconsistent edge control
outcomeMilestones.confident: Traverses smoothly and can sideslip when needed
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Precise control of traverse angle and sideslip speed

tips.title: Edge Angle Control
tips.content: To traverse, tilt both skis uphill. To sideslip, flatten your skis slightly.

tips.title: Ankles Are the Key
tips.content: Control edge angle from your ankles. Roll them uphill to grip, flatten to slip.

tips.title: Upper Body Faces Downhill
tips.content: Keep your shoulders and chest facing slightly downhill, even while traversing across.

tips.title: Weight on Downhill Ski
tips.content: Keep more weight on your downhill ski for stability during traverses and sideslips.

tips.title: Escape Route Skill
tips.content: Sideslipping lets you descend slopes that are too steep to turn on. It's your escape route.

drills.title: Edge Release Drill
drills.overview: Practice controlling sideslip speed through edge angle.

steps.instruction: Start on a moderate slope, skis across the fall line
Roll ankles uphill to set edges and stop
Slowly flatten your ankles to release edges
Slip sideways slowly - re-edge to stop
Practice varying your slip speed through ankle angle

skills.name: Speed Control
skills.summary: Manage your speed through turn shape and edge engagement.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Speed often builds beyond comfortable levels
outcomeMilestones.developing: Can slow down but not maintain consistent speed
outcomeMilestones.confident: Maintains desired speed through varied terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Instinctively adjusts speed through technique

tips.title: Turn Shape Matters
tips.content: Rounder turns across the fall line slow you down. More direct turns let you go faster.

tips.title: Complete Your Turns
tips.content: Finish each turn by coming across the hill. Incomplete turns let speed build.

tips.title: The 'S' Shape
tips.content: Think of making clean 'S' shapes in the snow. Each curve controls your speed naturally.

tips.title: Rhythm Over Braking
tips.content: Consistent turn rhythm is more efficient than alternating between speeding up and braking.

tips.title: Adjust for Terrain
tips.content: Steeper slopes need rounder turns. Flatter terrain allows more direct lines.

drills.title: Constant Speed Drill
drills.overview: Maintain the same speed from top to bottom using only turn shape.

steps.instruction: Pick a moderate blue run with consistent pitch
Start at a comfortable, moderate speed
Make turns that keep you at exactly that speed
steps.focusPoint: No speeding up or slowing down

steps.instruction: If you speed up, make rounder turns
If you slow too much, straighten your line slightly
Goal: Same speed top to bottom

skills.name: Linked Turns
skills.summary: Connect your turns into a smooth, rhythmic flow down the mountain.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Significant pause or hesitation between turns
outcomeMilestones.developing: Links turns but with inconsistent timing
outcomeMilestones.confident: Smooth, continuous turn transitions
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Effortless flow with varied rhythm

tips.title: Flow Like Water
tips.content: As one turn ends, immediately begin the next. Think of your skis as continuously flowing down the mountain.

tips.title: Count Your Rhythm
tips.content: Count '1-2-3, 1-2-3' as you turn. Keep a steady beat to maintain consistent timing.

tips.title: Breathe With Your Turns
tips.content: Exhale as you initiate each turn, inhale in the finish. Breathing adds rhythm naturally.

tips.title: No Traverse Between
tips.content: Avoid long traverses between turns. Each turn should flow into the next without pause.

tips.title: Weight Transfer Triggers
tips.content: The moment you finish one turn, shift weight to start the next. The transition is the trigger.

drills.title: Metronome Drill
drills.overview: Use a steady rhythm to link turns without pausing.

steps.instruction: Pick a comfortable green or blue run
Set a mental rhythm: '1-2-3' or 'turn-and-turn'
Start skiing, making one turn per beat
Keep the rhythm constant - no pausing
Maintain the same tempo from top to bottom
Try faster and slower rhythms on different runs

skills.name: Chairlift Loading & Unloading
skills.summary: Safely get on and off chairlifts.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Needs assistance with lift loading/unloading
outcomeMilestones.developing: Can load/unload but with occasional difficulty
outcomeMilestones.confident: Smooth, confident lift transitions
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Helps others and handles all lift types

videos.title: How to Use a Ski Lift

tips.title: Look Back
tips.content: When loading, look back over your shoulder to see the chair approaching.

tips.title: Skis Straight and Parallel
tips.content: Point your skis straight ahead when loading and unloading. Crossed tips cause falls.

tips.title: Sit Back Smoothly
tips.content: When the chair arrives, let it scoop you up. Sit back smoothly as it catches your legs.

tips.title: Tips Up at Unload
tips.content: Keep your ski tips up as you approach the unload ramp. Let the slope push you forward.

tips.title: Stand and Glide
tips.content: At unload, stand up as your skis touch snow, then glide straight out of the way.

items.text: Poles in one hand or clipped together
Look back to see approaching chair
Shuffle forward to the load line
Sit back smoothly as chair arrives

warnings.title: Safety Bar
warnings.content: Always lower the safety bar after loading. Keep it down until you reach the unload ramp.

skills.name: Basic Parallel Turns
skills.summary: True parallel skiing - both skis stay parallel throughout the turn.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Skis spread into wedge during turn initiation
outcomeMilestones.developing: Parallel on easy terrain, wedge on steeper
outcomeMilestones.confident: Consistent parallel turns on blue terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Effortless parallel turns with good edge engagement

tips.title: Weight Transfer
tips.content: Shift your weight from the old outside ski to the new outside ski to initiate the turn.

tips.title: Pole Plant
tips.content: A light pole touch helps with timing and rhythm. Plant as you start the new turn.

tips.title: Tip the Skis Together
tips.content: Think of tipping both skis onto their new edges at the same time. They move as a unit.

tips.title: Release to Initiate
tips.content: Start the new turn by releasing edge pressure, not by pushing. Let gravity help.

tips.title: Feet Under Hips
tips.content: Keep your feet hip-width apart throughout the turn. Too narrow or wide reduces stability.

drills.title: Direct Parallel Drill
drills.overview: Practice initiating turns without any wedge at all.

steps.instruction: Start on a comfortable blue run
From parallel, tip both skis to the new edges simultaneously
Don't allow any wedge opening - commit to the parallel
If you wedge, stop and restart more slowly
Focus on the transition between edges as the key moment

drills.title: Railroad Track Turns
drills.overview: Ski leaving two parallel tracks in the snow.

steps.instruction: Find fresh groomed snow where you can see your tracks
Make medium radius parallel turns
Look back at your tracks - they should be parallel like railroad tracks
If tracks spread apart (wedge), focus on keeping skis together
Repeat until you consistently leave parallel tracks

skills.name: Hockey Stop
skills.summary: A powerful parallel stop for quick, controlled stops.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot execute a parallel stop
outcomeMilestones.developing: Hockey stop works on one side but not the other
outcomeMilestones.confident: Quick hockey stops in either direction
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Precise stops at any speed, any direction

tips.title: Simultaneous Edge Set
tips.content: Both skis pivot and edge at the same time. Commit to the edge angle!

tips.title: Turn Your Feet, Not Body
tips.content: Your feet and skis rotate while your upper body stays facing downhill. Separation is key.

tips.title: Spray the Snow
tips.content: Imagine spraying snow to the side. If you're not making spray, you're not edging enough.

tips.title: Practice Both Sides
tips.content: Most skiers have a strong side. Practice your weak side twice as much to balance.

tips.title: Build Up Speed Gradually
tips.content: Start slow and add speed as you gain confidence. The technique is the same at any speed.

drills.title: Progressive Hockey Stop
drills.overview: Build hockey stop confidence with increasing speed.

steps.instruction: Start at very slow speed on a gentle slope
Pivot both skis sideways while staying centered
As skis turn sideways, dig in the edges to stop
Repeat at the same speed until consistent
Gradually increase your starting speed
Practice on both sides equally

skills.name: Introduction to Carving
skills.summary: Move from skidded turns to clean, carved arcs.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: All turns are fully skidded
outcomeMilestones.developing: Some carved sections but mostly skidding
outcomeMilestones.confident: Clean carved turns on groomed terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Railroad track carves with edge-to-edge transitions

tips.title: Trust the Edges
tips.content: Tip the skis on edge and let the sidecut do the work. No need to twist or push.

tips.title: Sidecut Magic
tips.content: Your ski's shape is designed to carve. When tipped on edge, it naturally arcs into a turn.

tips.title: Feel the Rail
tips.content: A good carve feels like riding on rails. The ski grips and tracks through the whole turn.

tips.title: Progressive Edging
tips.content: Gradually increase edge angle through the turn. Don't set the edge all at once.

tips.title: Check Your Tracks
tips.content: A carved turn leaves thin pencil lines. A skidded turn leaves wide brushed marks.

drills.title: J-Turn Carving Drill
drills.overview: Practice the carving sensation in the finish of turns.

steps.instruction: Start a parallel turn normally
In the last third of the turn, tip skis on a higher edge
Feel the ski grip and carve up the hill
Let the skis come to a natural stop through the carve
Check your track - it should be a thin curved line

drills.title: Traverse Tipping Drill
drills.overview: Practice tipping skis on edge while traversing.

steps.instruction: Start in a traverse across a blue run
While moving, progressively tip both skis uphill
Notice how the skis arc uphill as edge angle increases
Release edges and traverse again
Repeat, gradually increasing maximum edge angle

skills.name: Variable Terrain Adaptation
skills.summary: Adjust your technique for changing snow and terrain.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Struggles when conditions change
outcomeMilestones.developing: Adapts slowly to terrain changes
outcomeMilestones.confident: Smoothly handles varied groomed terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Proactively adjusts for all conditions

tips.title: Quiet Upper Body
tips.content: Your legs absorb terrain changes while your upper body stays calm and facing downhill.

tips.title: Soft Knees, Active Legs
tips.content: Keep your knees softly bent and ready to flex/extend. Stiff legs transmit every bump to your body.

tips.title: Read the Snow Ahead
tips.content: Look ahead to anticipate changes. Different snow textures have different colors and shine.

tips.title: Icy Patches: Smooth Edges
tips.content: On ice, use progressive, smooth edge engagement. Sudden edging will cause skid-outs.

tips.title: Crud: Stay Centered
tips.content: In heavy, chunky snow, keep centered and let your skis float up through the crud.

drills.title: Terrain Variety Run
drills.overview: Intentionally seek out different conditions on one run.

steps.instruction: Find a run with both sun and shade, or varied pitch
Ski through actively feeling the changes underfoot
Notice how your skis behave differently in each section
Adjust stance, edge angle, and speed for each condition
Repeat the run, trying to anticipate changes earlier

warnings.title: Ice Awareness
warnings.content: Ice is most common in high-traffic areas and shady spots. Reduce speed when approaching.

skills.name: Short Radius Turns
skills.summary: Quick, snappy turns for tighter spaces and speed control.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot maintain rhythm in short turns
outcomeMilestones.developing: Short turns but with speed building
outcomeMilestones.confident: Rhythmic short turns with good speed control
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Dynamic short turns in varied terrain

tips.title: Active Pole Plants
tips.content: Use rhythmic pole plants to set the timing for your turns.

tips.title: Quick Feet, Quiet Body
tips.content: Your feet move quickly under a stable upper body. Don't rotate your shoulders.

tips.title: Pole-Turn-Pole Rhythm
tips.content: Plant, turn, plant, turn. The pole plant triggers each new turn automatically.

tips.title: Stay in the Fall Line
tips.content: Short turns happen close to the fall line. Don't traverse between turns.

tips.title: Edge to Edge Quickly
tips.content: The faster you switch edges, the quicker your turn. Practice snappy transitions.

drills.title: Corridor Drill
drills.overview: Make short turns within an imaginary narrow corridor.

steps.instruction: Imagine a narrow corridor about 3 ski lengths wide
Make turns that stay within this corridor
Use pole plants to trigger each turn
Keep your upper body facing downhill
If you drift outside the corridor, reset and try again

drills.title: Thousand Steps Drill
drills.overview: Quick stepping turns to develop foot speed.

steps.instruction: Start on a moderate blue run
Make very small, quick direction changes
Think of your feet stepping quickly from side to side
Keep the rhythm going without pausing
Gradually make the turns more pronounced

skills.name: Advanced Carving
skills.summary: High-performance carving with extreme edge angles.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot maintain clean carves at higher speeds
outcomeMilestones.developing: Good carves but losing edge at high angles
outcomeMilestones.confident: Clean, high-angle carves with power
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Expert-level carving in all groomed conditions

tips.title: Angulation
tips.content: Create angles with your whole body - ankles, knees, hips all working together.

tips.title: Early Edge Engagement
tips.content: Get on edge early in the turn. The sooner you engage, the longer you carve.

tips.title: Commit to the Fall Line
tips.content: Advanced carving requires commitment. Let yourself fall into the turn, trusting your edges.

tips.title: Cross-Over vs Cross-Under
tips.content: At high speed, use cross-under transitions where your legs move under a stable upper body.

tips.title: Load and Explode
tips.content: Build pressure through the turn, then release explosively into the next turn.

drills.title: Javelin Turns
drills.overview: Lift the inside ski to force all weight on the carving outside ski.

steps.instruction: Start making carved turns on groomed blue terrain
As you initiate each turn, lift your inside ski off the snow
Point the lifted ski tip forward like a javelin
Hold the ski up through the entire turn
Set it down only to transition to the next turn

drills.title: Angulation Progression
drills.overview: Progressively increase edge angle through repeated runs.

steps.instruction: Run 1: Make moderate edge angle carves
Run 2: Increase angulation slightly - tip skis more
Run 3: Push further, get lower into the turn
Run 4: Find your current maximum edge angle
Check tracks - they should be thin and clean

warnings.title: Edge Blowout Risk
warnings.content: At extreme angles, edge failures happen fast. Always have an escape plan.

skills.name: Mogul Skiing
skills.summary: Navigate bump runs with control and style.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot maintain control in moguls
outcomeMilestones.developing: Survives moguls but loses rhythm
outcomeMilestones.confident: Consistent mogul line with absorption
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Fluid mogul skiing with varied tactics

tips.title: Absorb and Extend
tips.content: Retract your legs on top of the bump, extend into the trough.

tips.title: Pick Your Line First
tips.content: Before dropping in, scan the mogul field and identify your line through the first 5-6 bumps.

tips.title: Hands Forward
tips.content: Keep your hands well forward and visible. This prevents leaning back.

tips.title: Turn on the Bumps
tips.content: Use the back face of each bump as a platform to turn on. The bump helps pivot your skis.

tips.title: Zipper Line
tips.content: The zipper line goes straight down the trough. For control, ski a wider line using the bump faces.

drills.title: Single Bump Absorption
drills.overview: Practice absorbing one bump at a time.

steps.instruction: Find a groomed slope with a few isolated bumps
Approach a single bump at moderate speed
As you hit the bump, pull your knees up
Extend your legs on the backside
Repeat until absorption feels natural

drills.title: Three-Bump Challenge
drills.overview: Link turns through just three bumps with good form.

steps.instruction: Find an easy mogul field
Enter and link turns through exactly 3 bumps
Stop and reset. Assess: did you stay balanced?
Repeat until 3 bumps feel smooth
Gradually increase to 5, then 7, then full runs

warnings.title: Knee Stress
warnings.content: Moguls put high stress on knees. Warm up properly and know your limits.

warnings.title: Fatigue Factor
warnings.content: Mogul skiing is exhausting. Take breaks and don't push when tired.

skills.name: Steep Terrain
skills.summary: Conquer steep slopes with confidence and control.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot commit to the fall line on steep terrain
outcomeMilestones.developing: Survives steeps but with survival turns
outcomeMilestones.confident: Controlled skiing on black diamond terrain
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Dynamic, confident skiing on expert terrain

tips.title: Commit Forward
tips.content: On steep terrain, keep your weight forward. Leaning back puts you in the back seat and causes your skis to accelerate away from you.

tips.title: Fall Line Is Your Friend
tips.content: Turn INTO the fall line, not away from it. Quick commitment through the fall line actually gives you more control than trying to avoid it with traversing survival turns.

tips.title: Hands Forward and Visible
tips.content: Keep your hands where you can see them - forward and slightly apart. This positions your upper body correctly and prevents dropping a hand and rotating.

tips.title: Edge Release Timing
tips.content: On steep terrain, edge release must be decisive. A tentative release causes skidding; commit fully to releasing the edges and immediately engaging the new edges.

tips.title: Breathe Through Each Turn
tips.content: Anxiety causes breath-holding which creates tension. Exhale through each turn initiation - this relaxes your body and improves your movement patterns.

drills.title: Steeps Progression Drill
drills.overview: Build confidence on steep terrain by progressively increasing commitment to the fall line.

steps.instruction: Start on a moderate black run. Make rounded turns with full edge engagement at each turn finish.
steps.focusPoint: Establish confidence with round turn shapes

steps.instruction: Gradually make your turns more direct - spend more time pointed down the fall line between turns.
steps.focusPoint: Feel the acceleration through the fall line

steps.instruction: Add a pole plant just before each turn. The pole touch should pull your body forward and down the hill.
steps.focusPoint: Use pole plant to commit forward

steps.instruction: Focus on quick edge-to-edge transitions. The faster your edge change, the less you accelerate through neutral.

drills.title: Hockey Stop to Turn Drill
drills.overview: Use hockey stops as a foundation for building steep terrain confidence.

steps.instruction: Point straight down the fall line on a steep section and make an aggressive hockey stop.
steps.focusPoint: Feel the power of strong edge engagement

steps.instruction: Immediately release edges and pivot into another hockey stop on the opposite side.
steps.focusPoint: Quick transition from stop to turn

steps.instruction: Link these together: fall line - stop - pivot - fall line - stop - pivot.
Gradually round out the stops into actual turns, maintaining that same aggressive edge engagement.

warnings.title: Assess Before Entry
warnings.content: Always assess steep terrain before committing. Look for exits, obstacles, and other skiers. Check snow conditions - ice patches dramatically change edge grip.

warnings.title: Know Your Limits
warnings.content: Steeps amplify consequences of mistakes. Build up gradually over sessions - fatigue dramatically increases fall risk on expert terrain.

skills.name: Powder Skiing
skills.summary: Float through deep snow with proper technique.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Gets stuck or falls frequently in powder
outcomeMilestones.developing: Can ski powder on moderate terrain
outcomeMilestones.confident: Smooth powder skiing with good float
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Expert powder skiing in all depths

tips.title: Equal Weighting
tips.content: Keep weight more evenly distributed between both skis to float. Unlike hardpack where we weight the outside ski, powder requires a two-footed platform.

tips.title: Bouncing Motion
tips.content: Use a rhythmic up-and-down motion to unweight your skis through turns. The 'bounce' helps your skis rise and turn through the snow.

tips.title: Surf the Snow
tips.content: Think of powder skiing like surfing - maintain flow and rhythm. Let the snow support you rather than fighting through it.

tips.title: Narrower Stance
tips.content: Bring your feet slightly closer together than on hardpack. This creates a single platform that floats better than two separate skis.

tips.title: Speed Is Your Friend
tips.content: Maintain enough speed to stay afloat. Going too slow causes you to sink. Trust your skis and let them run.

drills.title: Dolphin Turns Drill
drills.overview: Develop the rhythmic up-and-down motion essential for powder skiing.

steps.instruction: On groomed snow, practice exaggerated up-and-down movements while making turns - bounce up to initiate, sink down to finish.
steps.focusPoint: Feel the rhythm of rise and sink

steps.instruction: Focus on both skis rising and sinking together. Your feet should move in unison, not independently.
Take this motion to shallow powder (a few inches). Feel how the bouncing motion helps your skis rise through the snow.
Gradually increase powder depth as your confidence grows. Maintain the same rhythmic pattern.

drills.estimatedReps: 5-10 turns per set, building depth progressively

drills.title: Platform Skiing Drill
drills.overview: Learn to ski on a two-footed platform for better float.

steps.instruction: On groomed snow, practice making turns with feet hip-width apart, weighting both skis equally.
steps.focusPoint: Feel balanced pressure on both feet

steps.instruction: Imagine your skis are bolted together and must move as one unit.
In powder, keep this same narrow, two-footed platform. Resist the urge to step or stem.

drills.estimatedReps: Full run focusing on platform skiing

warnings.title: Tree Well Danger
warnings.content: Tree wells in powder can be deadly. Never ski alone in deep powder near trees. If you fall, create an air pocket immediately.

warnings.title: Avalanche Awareness
warnings.content: Deep powder often means avalanche terrain. Check avalanche forecasts, carry proper safety equipment, and consider education courses before backcountry powder.

skills.name: Dynamic Short Turns
skills.summary: High-performance short turns for any terrain.

outcomeMilestones.needsWork: Cannot maintain dynamic short turns on steep terrain
outcomeMilestones.developing: Dynamic turns but speed builds
outcomeMilestones.confident: Powerful, controlled short turns anywhere
outcomeMilestones.mastered: Expert-level short turn mastery

tips.title: Explosive Transitions
tips.content: Use powerful leg movements to quickly switch edges and redirect your skis. The power comes from legs, not upper body rotation.

tips.title: Quiet Upper Body
tips.content: Keep your upper body facing down the fall line while your legs and skis pivot beneath you. Think 'hips to the valley' throughout.

tips.title: Machine Gun Pole Plants
tips.content: Quick, rhythmic pole plants set the timing. Plant - turn - plant - turn. The pole touch triggers each new turn.

tips.title: Load and Explode
tips.content: At the end of each turn, feel pressure build under your feet, then 'explode' out of that pressure to initiate the next turn. This creates the snap of dynamic short turns.

tips.title: Narrow Corridor
tips.content: Imagine skiing down a narrow corridor - your skis pivot quickly beneath you but your path stays controlled and consistent.

drills.title: Short Swing Rhythm Drill
drills.overview: Develop the rhythm and timing essential for dynamic short turns.

steps.instruction: Start on moderate terrain. Make very short-radius turns, counting 'one-two, one-two' to establish rhythm.
Add pole plants that sync with your count - plant on 'one', turn on 'two'.
Focus on keeping your upper body quiet while your legs do all the pivoting work beneath you.
Progressively increase speed while maintaining the same rhythm and upper body stillness.

drills.estimatedReps: 20-30 turns per set, focus on rhythm

drills.title: Pivot Slip Drill
drills.overview: Develop the rapid pivoting skills needed for dynamic short turns.

steps.instruction: Traverse across the hill. While moving, rapidly pivot your skis to face the other direction while continuing in the same direction of travel.
steps.focusPoint: Skis pivot independent of travel direction

steps.instruction: Chain these together: traverse - pivot - traverse - pivot. Feel how your skis can rapidly change direction.
Apply this pivoting action to actual turns down the fall line. The same quick pivot action powers dynamic short turns.

drills.estimatedReps: 6-8 pivot slips per traverse, both directions
